description: Dive into "Capturing the Heart of New Delhi" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capturing the Heart of New Delhi

places.generalDescription: India Gate, located at the eastern end of Raj Path in New Delhi, is a grand triumphal arch that serves as a war memorial for Indian soldiers who lost their lives in World War I. Designed by renowned architect Edward Lutyens and inaugurated in 1921, it commemorates over 70,000 Indian soldiers who perished during the war. The monument also honors more than 13,500 British and Indian soldiers killed in the Afghan war of 1919.

sources.snippet: Looking a little like the famous Arc de Triomphe in Paris, the equally impressive India Gate is a magnificent stone arch built as a memorial to Indian soldiers killed in WWI. An eternal flame burns beneath the massive structure, and its walls are inscribed with the names of more than 90,000 soldiers who died in the conflict. Standing on a base of red stone and featuring a shallow domed bowl on top that is occasionally filled with burning oil (usually only on important anniversaries), the structure dominates the parkland around it, an always busy area with crowds of tourists and locals alike enjoying a picnic or simply relaxing.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Delhi & New Delhi

sources.snippet: Constructed in 1921 in order to pay tribute to around 90,000 Indian Army soldiers who died in WWI, the Northwest Frontier operations and the 1919 Anglo-Afghan War, this imposing 42m high structure was modelled on Paris‚Äô Arc de Triomphe. There is a constant buzz in the park and pools surrounding the gate as families picnic on the grass and swim in the water. Vendors selling street food,  budhdhi ke bal (candyfloss or ‚Äòold lady‚Äôs hair‚Äô) and toys mill around beneath the arch and on the long road that leads from the presidential palace towards the arch.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable & Photogenic Spots in Delhi, India

sources.snippet: This towering war memorial archway pays tribute to the 70-thousand Indian soldiers who died in World War I fighting for the British army, and is a standard stop on every Delhi sightseeing tour. Originally called the All India War Memorial, it soars 40 metres high and is particularly striking at sunset when the light casts a soft glow over it. Looking for a place to stay in Delhi?

sources.snippet: The India Gate, built in 1931 and modeled off the Arc de Triomphe in Paris is a sight to see in itself, but the real attraction here is the  chaos and crowds of the surrounding park. From street vendors to school children, tourists, and performers, the park here is somewhere between a party and Times Square - and we just got a pack of bubbles and enjoyed the chaos.

places.name: India Gate

reviews.text:
India Gate remains one of the most iconic and well-maintained landmarks in Delhi. Visited over the weekend, and despite it being a popular spot, there was absolutely no wait time, which made the experience even better.

The surroundings were clean, the lawns were well-kept, and the atmosphere felt peaceful, especially around sunset. Perfect for photography lovers - the lighting and backdrop make for stunning pictures.
Security was visible but not intrusive, and crowd management was smooth. It's a great place to take a stroll, enjoy some quiet time, or just soak in the historic significance of the monument.

Highly recommended for both tourists and locals who want to experience a piece of India's heritage in a calm, scenic setting!

India Gate Morning Visit Review üáÆüá≥‚ú®

Visiting India Gate in the morning is a truly serene and patriotic experience. Here's a detailed review of my experience:

Perfect Morning Vibes üåÖ:
Early morning around 6-8 AM is the best time to visit. The rising sun adds a golden glow to the structure, making the view magical and peaceful.

Peaceful Atmosphere üïäÔ∏è:
Compared to the busy hours, the morning is calm, with fewer crowds. It allows you to enjoy the architecture and surroundings in peace.

Cleanliness & Maintenance üßπüåø:
The area is very neat and clean, with well-maintained gardens and tidy paths. Kudos to the authorities for keeping such a historic site spotless.

Ideal for Morning Walks & Jogging üëü:
Many locals come for jogging or yoga. The cool breeze and open space make it a refreshing start to the day.

Patriotic Feelings Evoked üáÆüá≥‚ù§Ô∏è:
Standing before the eternal flame and reading the names engraved on the monument fills your heart with pride and gratitude.

Perfect for Photography üì∏:
The soft light during the morning enhances the beauty of the monument and is ideal for taking stunning pictures.

Accessibility & Safety üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è:
Easily accessible and well-guarded by security. You feel completely safe while enjoying your visit.

In short, if you want a peaceful, clean, and meaningful experience at India Gate, plan your visit in the early morning hours. It will leave you refreshed, proud, and connected to the soul of India.

places.generalDescription: Gurudwara Sri Bangla Sahib, located near Connaught Place in New Delhi, is a significant Sikh place of worship. The complex features a stunning pool known as the Sarovar, reminiscent of the one at Amritsar's Harminder Sahib. The water in this lake is considered sacred and has purported healing properties.

sources.snippet: One of the most prominent religious places in India, Gurudwara Bangla Sahib is associated with the eighth Sikh Guru, Guru Har Kishan. A sacred shrine for Sikhs, this place has become a popular religious tourist attraction. People from every religion irrespective of caste, creed and colour visit the shrine to soak in the tranquility and serenity of the gurudwara.
sources.shortName: Delhi Darshan Tour - Best Day Sightseeing Places

sources.snippet: Gurudwara Bangla Sahib Temple is an island of tranquillity in the centre of one of the world‚Äôs most hectic and populous cities. Like all Sikh temples, everyone and anyone is welcome to wander inside to soak in the serene spirituality of the Gurudwara. It is the most prominent Sikh house of worship in Delhi.

places.name: Gurdwara Bangla Sahib

reviews.text:
Visiting Gurudwara Bangla Sahib is a deeply spiritual experience. The moment you step in, you're enveloped in peace and devotion. The divine atmosphere, Gurbani recitals, and Langar service create a sense of oneness with the Divine.
This revered Sikh shrine in New Delhi is a must-visit. Its cleanliness and serenity are truly remarkable. Do visit at night when it's beautifully lit up. And don't forget to savour the delicious 'Prasad' ( Langer) !

Gurudwara Shri Bangla Sahib Ji is truly one of the most serene and spiritually uplifting places in New Delhi. The moment you step through the gates, the chaotic noise of the city fades away, replaced by the calming sounds of kirtan (devotional music) echoing through the air. The golden dome glistening under the sky and the peaceful Sarovar (holy pond) create a deeply tranquil atmosphere that touches your soul.

The entire premises are immaculately maintained by devoted volunteers. One of the most humbling experiences is sitting in the Langar Hall, where a free, delicious vegetarian meal is served to all, regardless of caste, creed, or background. It's a true example of humanity, equality, and service.

I was especially moved by the kindness and discipline of the sewadars (volunteers). From guiding visitors to helping with the head covers and offering water and food, their dedication is inspiring. The museum and the library within the complex are also worth a visit for those interested in Sikh history and values.

Whether you're religious or not, a visit to Gurudwara Bangla Sahib will leave you feeling calm, grateful, and more connected. Highly recommended for locals and tourists alike.

It is located in a well accessed area..clearly visible from the main road. Visit it for its beauty that's a must see, for offering your prayers & for providing Sewa (your Services). There is peace, discipline & serenity irrespective of the temple being full of people. Must visit. üôè‚ú®

places.generalDescription: Swaminarayan Akshardham, inaugurated in 2005, is a breathtaking Hindu temple complex that showcases the rich tapestry of Indian culture and spirituality through its stunning architecture and artistry. Constructed over five years without steel, this remarkable site spans more than 32 acres and features exquisite materials like pink sandstone and white marble sourced from across India. The centerpiece is an impressive Mandir adorned with intricate carvings, including 20,000 stone figures representing India's revered saints and sages.

sources.snippet: Although only recently completed (it opened in 2007), the splendid Hindu Akshardham temple looks like it could be centuries old. Festooned with intricate and elaborate carvings, this magnificent building attracts countless visitors for its majestic beauty. Highlights include the stunning 43-meter-high main monument with its rich carvings of animals, plants, gods, dancers, and musicians, all made from pink sandstone and marble.

places.name: Swaminarayan Akshardham

reviews.text: A breathtaking masterpiece! Swaminarayan Akshardham in Delhi is a serene blend of spirituality, culture, and architectural brilliance. The carvings on the temple are incredibly detailed and awe-inspiring. The water show is a must-watch - truly magical. The entire complex is clean, well-organized, and peaceful. A perfect place to disconnect from the city's chaos and soak in divine energy. Highly recommended for all age groups!

I visited Akshardham Temple in Delhi and it was a great experience. The temple is very big, clean, and peaceful. As soon as I entered, I felt calm and happy. The design of the temple is beautiful. The walls and pillars have amazing carvings that show Indian culture and stories.
The place is very well-managed. The staff are kind and helpful. You can't carry your phone or camera inside, but that makes the visit more peaceful.
This place takes around 5 hours to explore completely, with a ticket of Rs 360.

places.name: Lotus Temple

reviews.text:
The Lotus Temple is one of the most peaceful and beautiful places in Delhi. The architecture is stunning-it really does look like a blooming lotus surrounded by water ponds. The best part is the calm and serene atmosphere inside the prayer hall, where people of all religions can sit quietly and meditate. The gardens around the temple are very well maintained and add to the beauty of the place.

Entry is free, but it's best to visit early in the morning or in the evening to avoid the heavy crowds and heat. Photography is allowed outside but not inside the prayer hall. Overall, it's a must-visit landmark if you're in Delhi, not just for the architecture but also for the unique sense of peace you feel here.

The Lotus Temple, located in New Delhi, India, is a stunning Baha'i House of Worship known for its unique lotus flower-inspired architecture. Completed in 1986, the temple features 27 marble-clad petals arranged in clusters of three, creating a breathtaking sight. The temple is open to people of all faiths and backgrounds, serving as a place of worship and contemplation. Its serene ambiance and beautiful gardens make it a popular tourist destination. The Lotus Temple symbolizes unity, peace, and spirituality, welcoming visitors from around the world. Its design has earned numerous accolades, and it has become an iconic symbol of India's rich cultural diversity. Visitors can explore the temple grounds, learn about the Baha'i faith, and experience a sense of tranquility amidst the bustling city. The Lotus Temple is a must-visit destination for those seeking spiritual enlightenment and architectural marvels.

Today, I visited the Lotus Temple in Delhi on my own, and although it wasn't my first time, the experience was still special in its own way. The temple is one of the most iconic landmarks in Delhi, known for its serene ambiance and its breathtaking lotus-shaped architecture.

Unfortunately, just as I arrived, it started raining heavily, which meant I couldn't actually enter the temple. This was my second attempt at visiting, and yet again, I had to admire it mostly from the outside. Despite that, the overall experience was memorable.

The Lotus Temple's design is truly a sight to behold. The white marble petals form a giant lotus, symbolizing purity, peace, and unity. Even from a distance, the temple exudes a sense of calm. Surrounded by lush green gardens, the area feels like a peaceful escape from Delhi's chaos. Standing there in the light rain, looking at the temple with droplets shimmering on the white marble, was almost meditative.

While I couldn't step inside this time, I still cherish the quietness and the spiritual vibe that the place radiates. I also appreciated how clean and well-maintained the premises are. The sound of rain on the leaves and pathways only made the experience more soothing.

If I had to sum it up:

Pros: Stunning architecture, peaceful surroundings, serene atmosphere

Cons: Entry can be restricted during rain, so plan accordingly

Even though I haven't yet fully explored the temple from the inside, I still find myself drawn to its energy. My love for this place grows with each visit, and I hope that on my third visit, I finally get to sit inside and experience the silence and tranquility that the Lotus Temple is famous for.

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (4/5, only because I couldn't enter due to rain!)

places.generalDescription: Lodhi Garden, a historic British-era public park in Delhi, is a lush oasis featuring ancient tombs, rose and herb gardens, bonsai trees, and a serene lake. The garden is home to architectural marvels from the 15th century by the Lodhi dynasty, including Mohammed Shah's Tomb, Tomb of Sikandar Lodi, Shisha Gumbad and Bara Gumbad.

sources.snippet: There‚Äôs no denying that central Delhi can become a little overwhelming at times; the sheer volume of traffic and people, the noise, and the pollution. Lodhi Garden is a peaceful oasis in the chaos. Located in the south of the city, the 90-acres of sculptured garden and monuments were created at the behest of Lady Willingdon, who had two villages cleared in 1936 to make space for her project.

places.name: Lodhi Garden

reviews.text:
A Peaceful Escape in the Heart of Delhi üåø

Lodhi Garden is truly a hidden gem in Delhi! I spent a wonderful time here and felt completely at peace. The entire place is quiet and calm-perfect for those looking to escape the city's chaos without actually leaving the city.

The gardens are lush and well-maintained, filled with beautiful flowers, tall trees, and historical monuments that add a charming touch to the surroundings. There are lovely fountains that create a relaxing vibe, and open spaces for outdoor games, yoga, or simply lounging around.

I saw people jogging, walking, playing badminton, and kids enjoying themselves freely. It's an ideal spot for a morning workout, a peaceful picnic, or just spending some quality time with yourself or loved ones.

Highly recommended if you're looking for a calm, refreshing break in nature right in the middle of Delhi.

Lodhi Garden is one of Delhi's most beautiful and peaceful escapes, blending lush greenery with centuries-old tombs and architecture. Ideal for morning walks, picnics, or photography, the garden features wide lawns, well-maintained flowerbeds, and shaded pathways. A highlight is the butterfly section, which adds a touch of color and serenity, especially for nature lovers and children. The atmosphere is calm, clean, and spacious-perfect for both leisure and quiet reflection. A must-visit for anyone seeking nature and history in the heart of Delhi.

The garden is filled with lush green trees, bushes, grass, and colorful flowers, along with old tombs that add a touch of history. It's a spacious place to explore, offering different views at every step. There's ample space to sit, relax, or enjoy outdoor games. Entry is free, making it a perfect spot for couples, friends, families, and children to spend quality time together.

places.address: Lodhi Rd, Lodhi Gardens, Lodhi Estate, New Delhi, Delhi 110003, India

places.generalDescription: The Red Fort, located in Old Delhi, India, is a 17th-century Mughal fortress made of red sandstone. It was the main residence of the Mughal Emperors and was commissioned by Emperor Shah Jahan in 1638. The fort's design is credited to Ustad Ahmad Lahori, who also built the Taj Mahal.

sources.snippet: The beautiful Red Fort (Lal Qila) was built by Shah Jahan in 1648 and served as the seat of Mughal power until 1857. This stunning structure, with its tall, red sandstone walls covers an area of more than two square kilometers, the entirety of which is crescent shaped and surrounded by a moat. The impressive main entrance, the Lahore Gate, is so named as it faces towards Lahore in Pakistan, while the even grander Delhi Gate was used by the emperor for ceremonial processions.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Delhi & New Delhi

sources.snippet: Delhi boasts of many historical treasures and architectural marvels but the gem in its crown has to be the Red Fort. One of the most popular Mughal monuments, made by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan, the fort served as a Mughal palace, housing Mughal emperors for almost 200 years. Not just a palace, the fort also served as the cultural and strategic hub for the Mughal empire.
sources.shortName: Delhi Darshan Tour - Best Day Sightseeing Places

This fort was again commissioned by Emperor Shah Jahan in 1639 when he shifted the capital from Agra to Delhi.

places.name: Red Fort

reviews.text:
The Red Fort is truly one of the most iconic landmarks of India and a must-visit in Delhi. üè∞
The architecture is stunning, with massive red sandstone walls, beautifully designed gates, and intricate carvings that showcase Mughal grandeur. Walking inside feels like stepping back into history.

The museum inside gives a good glimpse of India's rich heritage, and the evening light & sound show is an amazing experience that brings the fort's history to life.

‚úÖ Well-maintained in most parts
‚úÖ Good for photography üì∏
‚úÖ Great spot for history lovers and families

‚ö†Ô∏è Be prepared for crowds, especially on weekends. Carry water and wear comfortable shoes as the fort is huge and requires a lot of walking.

Overall, it's a perfect mix of history, culture, and beauty - a place every traveler should explore at least once!

As a foreign visitor, visiting the Red Fort early in the morning was an unforgettable experience. I arrived just before sunrise, and watching the first rays of light fall on the majestic red sandstone walls was simply breathtaking. The fort glowed in warm orange hues, and the peaceful atmosphere made it feel like time had slowed down.

The morning breeze, the quiet surroundings, and the birds chirping added to the beauty of the moment. Walking through the grand gates and exploring the historic structures inside felt like stepping back in time. I could sense the deep history and culture that this place holds.

After my visit, I felt calm, inspired, and deeply moved by the heritage of India. The Red Fort is more than just a monument - it's a symbol of strength, beauty, and tradition. A must-visit, especially in the peaceful hours of the morning. Highly recommended!

A must-visit spot in Delhi! The Red Fort is beautifully built and very well maintained. Inside, you'll find spacious gardens, grand halls, and peaceful pathways to walk around and enjoy.

The place is clean, organized, and has good facilities for visitors. Security is well-managed, with guards around to ensure safety. Great for a relaxed outing or some quiet exploration. I had a great deep dive in history. Lot of audio visual means to experience.

places.address: Netaji Subhash Marg, Lal Qila, Chandni Chowk, New Delhi, Delhi, 110006, India

reviews.text:
Sundar Nursery in Delhi is a hidden oasis of beauty and tranquility right in the heart of the city! This 90-acre heritage park is a perfect blend of lush greenery, stunning landscapes, and historical monuments, making it an ideal spot for nature lovers, history enthusiasts, and families alike.

The beautifully designed gardens are a treat to the eyes, with vibrant flower beds, serene water features, and well-maintained walking paths. The restoration of the Mughal-era monuments within the park adds a touch of history and charm, making it a unique experience. It's a great place to relax, take a stroll, or even have a picnic with friends and family.

What makes Sundar Nursery truly special is its peaceful ambiance-it's a refreshing escape from Delhi's chaos. The park is clean, well-organized, and offers plenty of shaded areas to sit and unwind. The entry fee is very reasonable, and the staff is friendly and helpful.

Whether you're looking for a quiet morning walk, a photography session, or just a place to reconnect with nature, Sundar Nursery is a must-visit. It's one of Delhi's best-kept secrets!

Pro Tip: Visit during the early hours or late afternoon for the best light and cooler weather. Don't forget to carry a camera-the place is incredibly photogenic‚Ä¶üí´üå∏ü•∞

A Hidden Gem in the Heart of Delhi!

Sunder Nursery is truly a breath of fresh air amidst the hustle and bustle of Delhi. From the moment you enter, you're greeted with beautifully maintained gardens, a peaceful atmosphere, and a perfect blend of history and nature. The landscaping is absolutely stunning ‚Äì vibrant flowers, heritage trees, lotus ponds, and wide green lawns make it a paradise for nature lovers and photography enthusiasts alike.

The historical monuments within the park are thoughtfully preserved and give a unique charm to the surroundings. It's a wonderful place for family outings, solo strolls, or peaceful reading under the shade of a tree. The walking paths are clean and well-laid, making it accessible for all ages.

The environment is calm, safe, and perfect for picnics or morning walks. There's also a charming caf√© offering snacks and drinks with a beautiful garden view. The entry is very affordable, and the overall experience feels like a world away from city chaos.

Sunder Nursery is not just a park ‚Äì it's an experience that nourishes the soul. Highly recommended for anyone looking to relax, reconnect with nature, or explore Delhi's rich heritage in a peaceful setting.

Sunder Nursery is truly a hidden gem in the heart of Delhi! üåø‚ú® The perfect blend of heritage, nature, and tranquility - with beautifully restored Mughal-era monuments, serene water bodies, and an incredible variety of trees, birds, and butterflies.

The lawns are well-maintained, pathways are wide, and the whole atmosphere feels peaceful despite being so close to the city bustle. It's also a great spot for photography, heritage walks, and even casual picnics with family and friends.

Highly recommend visiting early morning or late afternoon for the best experience. Definitely one of the most refreshing green escapes in Delhi! üå∏

places.generalDescription: The National Rail Museum in Delhi is a paradise for train enthusiasts, offering a captivating journey through the rich history and heritage of Indian railways. With over 100 real exhibits, including a remarkable 1855 steam locomotive, the museum showcases antique train furniture, railway equipment, historical photographs, and memorabilia. Visitors can marvel at the Fairy Queen, the world's oldest operating steam engine, and enjoy rides on a toy train around the museum grounds.

sources.snippet: Spread across 10 acres, the National Rail Museum houses more than 30 locomotives and several old carriages, most of them quite rare. All told, more than 140 years of Indian railway history has been preserved on this fascinating site, including an engine built in 1885 and the Fairy Queen steam engine from 1855. Other highlights include several unique items, such as a collection of saloon cars belonging to the country's once powerful Maharajas, including the teak carriage of the Maharaja of Mysore, covered with ivory; the cabin of the Prince of Wales from 1876; and the carriage in which the ashes of Gandhi were carried after his assassination in 1948.

reviews.text:
Visited on July 7th, 2025 ‚Äì Day 4 in India

After taking a break yesterday to explore the markets, we continued our sightseeing today with our private tour guide. Our morning began at Rajghat, and from there we made our way to Jama Masjid.

It's one of the largest mosques in India and a true architectural marvel, built centuries ago during the Mughal era. As soon as we arrived, we were swept into the lively energy of Old Delhi-the sounds, the colors, the movement-it's a kind of chaos that somehow feels alive and exciting rather than overwhelming.

The climb up the steps to the mosque was a fun adventure for our daughters (5 and 7), who took it on like a challenge and loved every minute. Once we entered the vast open courtyard, everything shifted. The noise faded, and it felt incredibly peaceful and calm inside. There's something very spiritual about standing there, surrounded by towering minarets, marble domes, and centuries of history.

Our girls were full of curiosity, asking questions about how people pray, what the call to prayer means, and why everyone was barefoot. It turned into a beautiful moment of quiet reflection and learning. We took our time to take it all in, and even in the middle of a bustling city, it felt like we were in our own quiet world.

We absolutely loved this visit-it was meaningful, memorable, and full of life. Highly recommend for anyone traveling through Delhi, especially with kids who are curious and adventurous üôèüèΩ.

These monuments are beautiful, amazingly and well built structures. The architecture is so impressive. Some of the structures are still intact. But the Place doesn't maintain properly it looks so dirty mainly in the exterior.

If you tour guide says this is biggest mosque of India, It is absolutely lies. Biggest mosque of India is in Bhopal (MP).
3 Onion Shapes domes with 2 Minars (Tower) this particular Persian design introduced by Shahjahan in 17th Century & copied by across the globe. Therefore, Jama Mosque is famous bcz of its unique architecture.
The mosque has a peaceful atmosphere despite being in the heart of busy Chandni Chowk. A must-visit for history, culture, and photography lovers!

places.generalDescription: The Indira Gandhi Memorial Museum in Delhi is a significant historical site, once the residence of the late Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. The museum showcases her life through photographs, personal belongings, news clippings, and letters. The surrounding garden has been transformed into a memorial with marked spots where she was assassinated. The well-maintained lawns and shady trees create a serene atmosphere around the off-white mansion.

sources.snippet: Another important politician-related attraction is the Indira Gandhi Memorial Museum, housed in the former residence of this much-revered woman (Indira was the daughter of India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, and although a friend of Mahatma Gandhi, was unrelated). Highlights include photos documenting her life and time as prime minister, personal belongings such as the sari she was wearing at the time of her assassination, along with news clippings and letters. An enclosed garden with mature trees and flowering plants surrounds the building, and its pathway is now a memorial, with the spot where she was assassinated clearly marked.

reviews.text:
A well-curated and historically significant museum showcasing the life and legacy of Indira Gandhi.
The preserved residence, personal artifacts, and photo galleries provide insight into key moments of Indian political history.
The memorial walkway marking the site of her assassination adds a powerful emotional dimension.
Worth a visit for anyone interested in India's modern political evolution.

On my recent trip to Delhi, I visited the Indira Gandhi Museum on 3rd May 2025. We reached around 12 pm. It is the same place where she resided along with her family. The place has been well maintained and showcases her entire life and political journey. There is her dressing room, her prayer room, dining area, drawing room and her office. It also shows the place where Rajiv Gandhi along with Sonia, Rahul and Priyanka used to stay. The path where she was assassinated is not open for public to go through but we can see it from afar. There is no entry fee. One can easily spend an hour here getting all the information. If you are a history lover, then you should definitely visit it.

I recently visited the Indira Gandhi Museum in Delhi and it was truly wonderful! The exhibits were well-maintained and provided a fascinating glimpse into her life and legacy. I loved learning about her contributions to India's history. What's remarkable is that I wasn't even born when she passed away, yet her impact is still felt today. I'd highly recommend this museum to anyone interested in history and politics. I'll definitely be back! It's one of the best places to visit in Delhi, offering a unique perspective on India's former Prime Minister.

places.generalDescription: Humayun‚Äôs Tomb is an opulent red-sandstone tomb of Mughal Emperor Humayun, built in 1572 and surrounded by formal gardens. The monument rises gracefully from lush gardens and is surrounded by a symmetrical charbagh, exuding an air of tranquility and grandeur. Its construction with red sandstone and white marble creates a captivating contrast on the facade, making it visually delightful for visitors and photographers.

sources.snippet: The tomb of Mughal Emperor Humayun is a real architectural wonder and one of the most impressive buildings in the whole of Delhi. Predating the Taj Mahal by around 60 years, it is thought to have inspired India‚Äôs most famous structure, although, rather than being built entirely from in white, the marble is reserved for the enormous dome and the inlays of the red sandstone arches, all of which follow the strict rules of Islamic geometry. The complex and its perfectly manicured gardens contain a number of other monuments and tombs, but none are quite as impressive or Instagram-worth as the tomb of Humayun.

sources.snippet: Set in a lovely, large square garden, Humayun's Tomb is a lofty mausoleum constructed of white marble and red sandstone. It was designed as a prototype of the Taj Mahal in Agra and is an excellent example of Mughal architecture. Built in the mid-16th century by Haji Begum as a memorial to her husband by Humayun's senior widow, the tomb is surrounded by lush formal gardens and other tombs including Humayun's barber and the Tomb of Isa Khan (the architect of the Taj Mahal), a fine example of Lodi architecture and octagonal in shape.

reviews.text: Humayun's Tomb is such a beautiful place in Delhi, it feels like walking into history. Built by his wife after he died, the tomb is surrounded by huge gardens and peaceful water pools. The red stone and white marble looks stunning, specially when sunlight falls on it. It's not just a tomb, it's like a memory of love and respect. You can feel a calm vibe there, far from city noise. The architecture is so grand but also somehow simple. I really think everyone should visit once, to see how beautiful and emotional history can be.

Humayun's tomb has a good Mughal architecture, a grand dome and intricate carvings. It is surrounded by well-maintained gardens with fountains. Its impressive tomb and surrounding structures are equally fascinating. It's a great place for photography, and to spend some quiet time away from the city's clamor. The tomb is surrounded by huge gardens and water pools. Its architecture is grand but simple. It's a tomb made for love and respect so please show some respects and there. It is one of the amazing UNESCO world heritage sites in Delhi by rating of 4.7/5 . When I entered feels drop in temperature & the gentle flow of cool air.  Must visit place in Delhi.  Tickets for Indian is just rs 40/ and if you pay online it's only Rs 35. And for foreigners it's Rs 600 on cash and Rs 550 via online payment.

Humayun's Tomb is a must-visit in Delhi and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The monument is stunning with its grand Mughal architecture, beautiful gardens, and peaceful atmosphere. Often called a precursor to the Taj Mahal, it offers a glimpse into history and is perfect for photography and walks. The site is well maintained and easy to reach by metro. A visit here feels like stepping into the Mughal era, making it one of the finest heritage spots in the city.

places.generalDescription: Jantar Mantar, a remarkable site built in 1724 under the direction of Mughal emperor Muhammad Shah, is an extraordinary collection of 13 architectural astronomical instruments. This UNESCO World Heritage Site, crafted by Maharaja Jai Singh II of Jaipur, showcases the ingenuity and scientific prowess of its time. Designed to track celestial movements‚Äîsuch as those of planets and stars‚Äîthese impressive structures feature intricate Zodiac illustrations and stunning curves that captivate visitors.

sources.snippet: Located near Connaught Place, one of New Delhi's largest and best-known business districts, Jantar Mantar is one of five astronomical observatories constructed by Maharajah Jai Singh I in 1725. Designed to enable occupants to observe the movements of the sun, moon, and planets, this well-preserved historic site also boasts several other old instruments on display that were once used to track the course of heavenly bodies and predict eclipses. Highlights of this remarkable and architecturally pleasing building include an enormous sundial known as the Prince of Dials.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Delhi & New Delhi

sources.snippet: A keen astronomer, Maharaja Jai Singh II of Jaipur, constructed five major Jantar Mantar in Jaipur, Delhi, Ujjain, Mathura and Varanasi. The Jantar Mantar in Delhi has three of the total thirteen astronomical instruments. The purpose of Jantar Mantar was to collect astronomical data and compile them to predict the movements of the sun, moon, planets and stars to tell the time.

places.name: Jantar Mantar

reviews.text:
Visited Jantar Mantar recently and it was a fascinating experience. The site is full of massive astronomical instruments built centuries ago, and it's amazing to see how advanced the science of timekeeping and astronomy was at that period. The architecture is unique, and every structure has its own purpose, which makes it a great spot for history and science lovers.

However, the place could be better maintained and there aren't many detailed descriptions near the instruments, so it's best to hire a guide if you want to properly understand everything. The area is spacious and photogenic, perfect for those interested in heritage and learning.

Overall, it was a memorable visit, blending history, science, and architecture all in one place. A must-visit if you are exploring Delhi!

Also you can spend some good time here. It is an astronomical observatory featuring a collection of unique architectural astronomical instruments.

Jantar Mantar in Delhi is a fascinating historical observatory that showcases the brilliance of Indian astronomy. Built by Maharaja Jai Singh II in the 18th century, it features massive instruments used for measuring time and celestial movements. The architecture is unique, and the precision of the instruments is impressive even today. It's a must-visit for history and science enthusiasts. The place is well-maintained, though visiting in cooler months is recommended due to Delhi's heat. A great spot to explore and learn!
A must visit place in Delhi.Its good to look if you are interested in knowing more about science and architecture.

Tickets can be booked both online and offline.

It was less crowded during our visit.

places.generalDescription: The National Zoological Park, located near Purana Qila in Delhi, is a renowned zoo in India that was inaugurated in 1959. Home to around 130 species including white tigers, elephants, and rhinos, it covers an expansive area of 176 acres and serves as a breeding ground for endangered animals. The park aims to be a model zoo for the country. Visitors can enjoy the diverse wildlife and lush surroundings while exploring the grounds.

sources.snippet: The National Zoological Park or commonly known as Delhi Zoo is an extensive zoo that spreads across 176 acres near the Old Fort in Delhi, India. In the middle of a vibrant city lies a 16th century citadel, a green island and a great collection of rare flora and fauna. Around 1350 animals are protected inside the zoo, of different species and families.

places.name: National Zoological Park, Delhi

reviews.text:
The National Zoological Park, commonly known as Delhi Zoo, is a 176-acre facility located near the historic Purana Qila in New Delhi, India. Established on November 1, 1959, the zoo is home to approximately 1,350 animals representing around 130 species from across the globe. ‚Äã

Key Attractions:

Diverse Wildlife: The zoo houses a variety of animals, including the Royal Bengal Tiger, Indian Rhinoceros, Asiatic Lion, and numerous bird species. ‚Äã

Conservation Efforts: It participates in breeding programs for endangered species such as the Bengal Tiger, Indian Rhinoceros, and Asiatic Lion. ‚Äã

Visitor Information:

Timings: The zoo operates from 8:30 AM to 5:30 PM, with the last entry at 4:30 PM. It remains closed on Fridays. ‚Äã

Tickets: Tickets are available exclusively online and can be booked up to 14 days in advance. ‚Äã

Facilities: Visitors can rent battery-operated vehicles for a guided tour of the zoo. Basic amenities like restrooms are available; however, there are no cafes or canteens inside, and outside food is not permitted. Carrying water is advisable. ‚Äã

Best Time to Visit: The winter months, from October to March, offer pleasant weather, making it an ideal time to explore the zoo. ‚Äã

Additional Tips:

Attire: Wear comfortable shoes and clothing suitable for walking. If visiting with young children, consider bringing a stroller. ‚Äã

Safety: Always maintain a safe distance from the enclosures and follow the zoo's guidelines to ensure a secure and enjoyable experience.‚Äã

A visit to the National Zoological Park offers an educational and engaging experience, highlighting India's rich biodiversity and ongoing conservation efforts.

One of the Best Places for a Day Out in Delhi!

Delhi Zoo (National Zoological Park) is undoubtedly one of the best places in Delhi for a fun and educational day outing, especially with kids. It's a famous tourist attraction that offers a chance to see a wide variety of animals and mammals including lions, elephants, white tigers, hippos, deer, and many more!

Kids absolutely love the experience - from watching majestic animals up close to exploring the Reptile House, which showcases snakes, crocodiles, and other reptiles.

The entry fee is very reasonable - ‚Çπ40 for kids and ‚Çπ80 for adults. There's ample paid parking space, and refreshment shops are available inside the zoo for snacks and drinks. A proper food court is located just outside the zoo as well, so you won't go hungry.

The nearest metro station is Supreme Court Metro Station, making it easily accessible. Just note that the zoo is closed on Fridays, so plan accordingly.

Highly recommended for families, nature lovers, and tourists exploring Delhi! üåøü¶Åüêòüêä

Visited the National Zoological Park in Delhi recently and had a pretty good experience overall. The place is huge and has a decent variety of animals ‚Äì from tigers and leopards to elephants, deer, birds, and reptiles. It's a nice green space in the middle of the city, which makes it feel peaceful and refreshing.

What I really liked was how spacious and clean the zoo was, especially compared to what I expected. The enclosures seemed reasonably maintained, and some animals looked quite active. Renting an e-cart was a good decision since the zoo is spread out ‚Äì definitely recommended if you're going with family or elders.

A few downsides though: some enclosures felt a bit empty or under renovation, and I wish there were better signs or information boards about the animals. Food options inside were also pretty limited, so it's a good idea to carry your own snacks and water (though outside food isn't allowed inside).

Overall, it's a nice spot to spend 2‚Äì3 hours, especially with kids or if you're a nature lover. Wouldn't say it's a "must-visit" in Delhi, but definitely worth checking out at least once.

places.generalDescription: The National Crafts Museum & Hastkala Academy, also known as the National Handicrafts and Handlooms Museum, is a sprawling complex resembling a traditional Indian village. It was established by freedom fighter Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay and houses over 35,000 distinct pieces of handiwork from various communities across India. The museum showcases textiles, tribal crafts, courtly crafts, and offers a glimpse into daily rural life with its village complex spread over 5 acres.

sources.snippet: The Crafts Museum-officially named the National Handicrafts and Handlooms Museum, New Delhi-displays a wide variety of traditional crafts from across India. Among its many fascinating features is the chance to watch highly skilled craftspeople demonstrate their centuries-old skills, as well as see large collections of textiles, woodwork, and ceramics. Also of interest are architectural displays of various regional villages, including authentic mud huts and a full-sized wooden haveli (a form of mansion house) from Gujarat decorated with traditional folk art and featuring exquisite woodcarvings, paintings, papier-m√¢ch√©, and embroidery.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Delhi & New Delhi

sources.snippet: The National Crafts Museum was a surprise - we did not expect to enjoy it as much as we did. There are recreations of classic villages, and Artisans demonstrate traditional embroidery, weaving, carving and pottery. Just at the entrance is Cafe Lota - a gorgeous, Instagrammable cafe that feels millions of miles away from the chaos of Old Delhi.

places.name: National Crafts Museum & Hastkala Academy

reviews.text:
It is near Pragati Maidan. You can see beautiful things made by hand, like paintings, pottery, clothes, and woodwork from different parts of India.
There is a special area called Village Complex where they have made small villages. It looks like a real Indian village. You can also watch artists making crafts in front of you.
The place is clean, quiet, and good for people who love art and culture. There is also a shop where you can buy handmade items.

If you're looking for a calm and relaxing place in the middle of the city, the National Craft Museum is a great pick. It's peaceful, full of beautiful traditional art, and perfect for a slow stroll. One of the best parts is the pottery section - you can actually try making your own pottery for a small fee, which is super fun!

There's also a small theatre where they sometimes show performances or craft-related films. The museum has a canteen if you get hungry, and a few shops where you can buy handmade stuff - great for gifts or souvenirs.

They've got lockers to keep your stuff safe, clean washrooms, and free drinking water too. Overall, it's a chill spot to spend a few hours, especially if you're into crafts or just want a break from the usual city chaos

Namaskaram!
I went on 20th July 2025 at 12 PM alone. Entry was free of cast for Indian citizens. It took 3 hours for me to visit entire area. And I couldn't focus on the details of the museum even I was there for 3 hours. My experience was very good, very very good. I have visited many places in Delhi for the last one and a half years and but this was my best experience so far. The peace of this place won my heart. I reached here at 12 PM and left at 3:00 PM. Despite spending 3 hours here, I could not see the things here closely. I could not even see many crafts properly. I started with crafts. After seeing all the crafts and artifacts, I went for a natural experience. I was mesmerized by what I saw there. Birds that are not commonly seen in many places these days, like parrots, woodpeckers, etc. were also present there. Although there were many other birds present there, seeing the parrot and woodpeckers made my heart very happy because I saw them after about 10 to 15 years. And I don't know how to explain the experience of nature that was happening there, you can only feel it by going there. By going there you will get to know many things about the history of our country. It is a very beautiful place, very beautiful. Those brothers and sisters whose parents are fond of nature should definitely go there. Thank you. Have a nice day üòä.

places.generalDescription: The Sulabh International Museum of Toilets in Delhi offers a unique and intriguing look at the history of sanitation and toilets. The museum showcases a diverse collection of artifacts, photographs, and displays that trace the evolution of toilets from ancient civilizations like Harappan and Mohenjo-Daro to modern times. Visitors can marvel at rare items such as silver and gold toilets, as well as a two-storeyed toilet from the USA dating back to the 1920s.

sources.snippet: The Sulabh International Museum of Toilets provides a fascinating look at sanitation and its connection to social reform. Displays show the evolution of the toilet and their various designs, with toilet-related items dating back to 2,500 BC, along with exhibits showing historical trends. Facts, photos, and artifacts present a chronology of developments relating to technology, social customs, toilet etiquette, and sanitary conditions, with exhibits including privies, chamber pots, toilet furniture, bidets, and water closets from 1145 to modern times.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Delhi & New Delhi

places.name: Sulabh International Museum Of Toilets

reviews.text:
This is THE definitive museum of Delhi.  With an incredibly warm staff and helpful signs and more different types of bathrooms and toilets than I ever thought possible in one place this is a must see in Delhi.

The museum strikes an incredible balance between taking this important subject, seriously, and promoting public health, including the pivotal role in India and public health research has had and making us all healthier while maintaining a great humorous and accessible side to human bodily functions.  Our kids enjoyed learning about the deep ancient roots of the modern toilet system and funny humorous takes and comics that they had posted in the museum about bathroom situations.  They have relics and specimens of toilets from almost every age in history.

This is easy access to the airport, and a great option if you have only a few hours for a layover and don't want to fight through the murderous traffic to red fort.

Sulabh international Museum of Toilets is a unique place of visit , which has been made possible by the untiring and deep rooted efforts of Dr. Bindeshwar Pathak , founder of the Sulabh Sanitation movement. He was instrumental in creating this awareness amongst the masses and the need for hygiene and sanitation at grassroot level. He's a Padma Vibhushan awardee . One can see the origin of the toilets , the various types of toilets , toilets meant for different classes , toilets used around the world etc. Sulabh toilets can be seen all around the country. They have lately also diversified into recycling of waste water, sewer treatment plants, bio waste management. Must visit museum in Delhi.

Review: Sulabh International Museum of Toilets ‚Äì A Thought-Provoking Visit

I recently had the opportunity to visit the Sulabh International Museum of Toilets in Delhi with my son, with the purpose of introducing him to the importance of solid waste management and environmental awareness. What we experienced there was far more enriching than we had anticipated.

The museum, established by Dr. Bindeshwar Pathak, is a unique and insightful space dedicated to the history and evolution of toilets from ancient times to the modern era. The museum manager personally guided us through the exhibits, providing a detailed and engaging explanation of the transformation of sanitation practices across various civilizations. From primitive open defecation systems to intricate medieval commodes and modern bio-toilets, the collection showcases how hygiene, technology, and culture have shaped toilet design over centuries.

Each exhibit was not only informative but also deeply thought-provoking. It was eye-opening to realize how much of a role sanitation plays in shaping public health and dignity, especially in developing countries like India. The historical context provided added a fascinating dimension-underlining how societies, both ancient and modern, have grappled with the challenges of waste management.

For my son, the visit was an excellent learning experience. He came away with a deeper understanding of how poor sanitation impacts the environment and human health, and why change is necessary. The session was more than just an academic exploration-it was a call to action.

India, with its growing population and urban sprawl, urgently needs a sanitation revolution, and institutions like Sulabh are doing commendable work in spreading awareness. I highly recommend this museum to parents, educators, and policymakers alike. It is a place where history, science, and social responsibility come together to inspire a cleaner, more conscious future.

reviews.text:
Lovely historical site! Beautiful architecture, and much less busy than some of the more popular sites. There is lots of space to walk around, and plenty of places to take cool pictures. The history of the site was also fascinating, especially for me as an American.
Cost for a foreigner to get in was 250, so not terrible, and that price also gets you a tour from one of the guards.

Decided to drop by as it was too early to go where we wanted to go. Great place with no queues or crowds. Had issues purchasing the tickets as they only have it online and the UI is not very good. In the end had to use alternative methods to purchase the tickets. Had a guide who shared about the fort. Make sure you visit the tomb which is across the road. Highly recommended if you want to avoid the crowds.

Tughlaqabad Fort, a 14th-century marvel in Delhi, is a must-visit for history buffs! Built by Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq in 1321, this massive fort with its towering stone walls and 13 remaining gates showcases Tughlaq dynasty architecture. Highlights include the underground passages, rainwater tanks, and the nearby red sandstone mausoleum. The fort's rocky hill setting and eerie legend of a Sufi saint's curse add mystique, though it was abandoned just six years after construction. Open 7 AM‚Äì5 PM, entry is INR 20 for Indians, INR 200‚Äì250 for foreigners. Easily reachable via Tughlaqabad Metro Station, it's a captivating, slightly haunting glimpse into Delhi's past. Ghiyasuddins tomb is just adjacent. North Western part of the fort is not open to tourists. Limited car Parking available.

reviews.text: Hauz Khas Fort is a peaceful historic site in South Delhi, dating back to the 13th century. Overlooking a serene lake, the fort features ancient ruins, a madrasa, mosque, and tomb built in Indo-Islamic style. It's perfect for a quiet stroll, photography, or watching the sunset. Entry is free, and the site is open from sunrise to sunset. While there's limited signage, the atmosphere is rich with history. Located next to Hauz Khas Village, you can explore cafes and shops nearby. Accessibility is limited due to uneven terrain, and there are no restrooms on-site. Despite minor maintenance issues, it's a great spot for history lovers or anyone seeking calm in the city.

Peaceful, historic, and unexpectedly scenic ‚Äì Hauz Khas Fort is one of my favorite hidden corners in Delhi. Nestled behind the lively Hauz Khas Village, the fort offers a calm escape with stunning views of the lake and crumbling stone architecture that tells stories from the 14th century.

Great spot for:

Quiet walks

Golden hour photos

Reading or reflecting

Exploring old ruins at your own pace

It's free to enter and usually not too crowded, especially on weekday mornings or evenings. The view of the lake from the back of the fort is absolutely worth the visit. Afterward, you can hop into one of the nearby cafes for a coffee or snack-everything is within walking distance.

Only downside: the fort could be cleaner in places. Some graffiti and litter take away from the beauty a bit.

But overall, a must-visit if you're into history, peaceful vibes, or just want a break from the usual Delhi hustle.

üì∏ Tip: Bring a camera-the light near sunset is magical here.

Hauz Khas Fort is a beautiful place with a lovely atmosphere. From here, you can also enjoy views of the Deer Park and the lake, which makes the visit more peaceful and scenic. The fort itself is not very large, but it's still worth visiting for its charm, history, and surroundings. A good spot for photography, walks, and spending some quiet time.

reviews.text: It's one of the best place to explore around South-West of Delhi. It has calm and pleasing atmosphere, and well maintained surroundings. You can go there for evening strolls, beautiful photographs with Qutub Minar as your background. It has Cafe there as well. The ticket was 50 for each Indian.

I visited this place as part of a heritage walk, and it was an incredible experience. The tour was well-organized and very informative. To enter the park, you need to buy a ticket on-site. Inside, you'll find a beautiful tomb, a serene water lake, a cozy caf√©, and a museum that adds depth to the historical significance of the site. The highlight for me was the stunning sunset view!

Mehrauli Archaeological Park is a beautiful historical site. To get here, take the metro to Qutub Minar station, then walk about 1 km to reach the park. Spanning over 200 acres, it's best suited for those who enjoy walking and exploring.

The park is home to several notable monuments like Jamali-Kamali Mosque and Tomb, Rajon Ki Baoli, Quli Khan's Tomb, Caf√© Stoned, and more. There's an entry fee of ‚Çπ50 per person at the Quli Tomb entrance.

The area is lush with greenery and very peaceful - the only sound you'll hear is an airplane passing overhead every couple of minutes. From here, you can also enjoy a great view of the Qutub Minar. The place isn't very crowded, likely because most visitors head straight to Qutub Minar, so you can explore in peace.

It's a lovely spot to spend the day with your loved ones, and it's also kid-friendly. I had a really nice experience here ‚ù§Ô∏è

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of central Delhi, Lodhi Art District is a vibrant hub of creativity and heritage. The off-white walls are adorned with colorful and unique graffiti that captivates visitors. This open-air art district, located near Lodhi Garden, offers a perfect backdrop for photography enthusiasts seeking trendy and Instagram-worthy spots. Created by St+Art, an NGO dedicated to open-space artwork, this area showcases the fusion of art and urban culture in India's first public art district.

sources.snippet: Back in 2015, the  St+art India Foundation, an organization dedicated to making art more accessible, teamed up with the Indian government to allow street artists to use the buildings in this inner-city neighbourhood as enormous canvases. As a result, what was once a rather dull stretch of government housing blocks is now home to over 50 vibrant murals created by local and foreign artists, covering themes ranging from Indian culture and celebrities to social issues. places.name: Lodhi Art District

reviews.text: Tucked away in the calm lanes of Lodhi Colony, the Lodhi Art District is one of Delhi's most unexpected treasures. Since 2015, thanks to the St+art India Foundation, over 50 artists from India and around the world have turned these walls into giant canvases bursting with colour and stories. It's the kind of place where you lose track of time, strolling past vibrant murals, snapping street shots, or just soaking it all in. The best part? It's open all day, every day, and absolutely free. Just hop off at Jor Bagh Metro (Yellow Line) and let the art find you

The art there is really good and just right for pictures and all, but do keep in mind that the place is not like a specific venue, it's just a whole colony with a wall painted in each block, so do visit when you've got time to search the walls and it's better if you have a vehicle to roam the district.
Just remember to have fun.
(Wanted to give 3.75/5 ‚≠ê but no such option)

A new experience. Not bad place, Arts which I've seen were impressive, I was thinking of artists who did that were very talented to express inner self through colours and shapes, I liked that painting had a message as well.
If to tell about practical side, it's located in living quarters, and art walls were not in every House, so roaming around in car or two wheeler is quite convenient to find art objects, rather than walking in hot weather.

places.generalDescription: The Garden of Five Senses is a sprawling 20-acre public park in Delhi, featuring various thematic areas such as Mughal gardens, pools of water lilies, bamboo courts, and herb gardens. It offers a serene ambiance with fountains, sculptures, and cultural events that stimulate all five senses. The immaculately designed landscape includes walking trails and restaurants, making it popular among couples seeking a romantic getaway.

sources.snippet: If an artistic theme is what you seek for your pictures, then The Garden of Five Senses will not disappoint you at all. From rugged rocky stances to waterfalls to modern art installation and water pools with lotuses & waterlilies, this one has an array of backdrops you can use.

sources.snippet: Your feet might give up, but the garden will never give up on you. We guarantee not one but many Instagrammable spots in Delhi, all a few steps away from each other. Hidden caf√©s, secret corners and vast gardens will tick your discovery nerve.

places.name: The Garden of Five Senses

reviews.text: The Garden of Five Senses is located around 3 km from Saket Metro Station. Though officially a public garden, in reality it feels more like a quiet forest space. It's most popular among couples looking for privacy and peaceful surroundings. The inner areas of the garden are mostly occupied by couples, and you'll find very few families or groups there. Families that do visit usually stay near the outer lawns or picnic areas, unaware of the deeper sections. For solo visitors, the garden is great if you're looking for greenery, silence, or a nature walk. The place is well-maintained and entry is affordable. Just know in advance - this is more of a couple-friendly spot than a typical family park.

The Garden of Five Senses is beautifully landscaped and well-kept, offering a peaceful escape from the city. However, please note: this garden is primarily a popular hangout spot for couples. Almost every corner has couples spending private moments, which might make it uncomfortable for families or solo visitors looking for a quiet stroll.

üéü Ticketing:
There is no online booking facility ‚Äì tickets are sold only at the gate and strictly by cash. Entry fee is ‚Çπ35 per person. Be sure to carry exact change, especially ‚Çπ5 coins or notes, as the staff often refuse to give smaller denominations and may ask you to bring change yourself.

‚úÖ Pros:

Beautiful, green, and well-maintained

Great for photography and nature walks

Calm atmosphere if you're visiting as a couple

‚ùå Cons:

Not suitable for family outings

Public display of affection is common

No digital payment or online booking

The Garden of Five Senses in Delhi is a peaceful retreat with lush greenery, themed gardens, and artistic installations-perfect for nature lovers and photographers. Located near Saket Metro Station (around 2 km away), it's easily accessible. From the station, an auto ride costs about ‚Çπ50. A great spot to relax, enjoy a walk, or spend quality time with friends and family.
